Federated Learning from Heterogeneous Data via Controlled Bayesian Air Aggregation

Tomer Gafni, Kobi Cohen, Yonina C. Eldar T. Gafni and K. Cohen are with the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Beer-Sheva, Israel (e-mail:gafnito@post.bgu.ac.il; yakovsec@bgu.ac.il). Yonina C. Eldar is with the Math and CS Faculty, Weizmann Institute of Science, Rehovot, Israel (e-mail: yonina.eldar@weizmann.ac.il). This work was supported by the Israel Science Foundation under Grant 2640/20. A short version of this paper that introduces the COBAAF algorithm, and preliminary simulation results was presented in Proceedings of the 58th Annual Allerton Conference on Communication, Control, and Computing (Allerton) [1]. In this journal version we include: (i) A detailed discussion on the implementation of the BAAF and COBAAF algorithms; (ii) a deep theoretical analysis of the algorithms with detailed proofs; (iii) more extensive simulation results; and (iv) a detailed discussion of the results, and comprehensive discussion and comparison with the existing literature.
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is an emerging machine learning paradigm for training models across multiple edge devices holding local data sets, without explicitly exchanging the data. Recently, over-the-air (OTA) FL has been suggested to reduce the bandwidth and energy consumption, by allowing the users to transmit their data simultaneously over a Multiple Access Channel (MAC). However, this approach results in channel noise directly affecting the optimization procedure, which may degrade the accuracy of the trained model. In this paper we jointly exploit the prior distribution of local weights and the channel distribution, and develop an OTA FL algorithm based on a Bayesian approach for signal aggregation. Our proposed algorithm, dubbed Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated learning (BAAF), is shown to effectively mitigate noise and fading effects induced by the channel. To handle statistical heterogeneity of users data, which is a second major challenge in FL, we extend BAAF to allow for appropriate local updates by the users and develop the Controlled Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated-learning (COBAAF) algorithm. In addition to using a Bayesian approach to average the channel output, COBAAF controls the drift in local updates using a judicious design of correction terms. We analyze the convergence of the learned global model using BAAF and COBAAF in noisy and heterogeneous environment, showing their ability to achieve a convergence rate similar to that achieved over error-free channels. Simulation results demonstrate the improved convergence of BAAF and COBAAF over existing algorithms in machine learning tasks.

I Introduction

In recent years, machine learning algorithms have given rise to advances in multiple fields, such as natural language processing, computer vision, and speech recognition [2]. Since these algorithms are data driven, their success hinges on vast amounts of training data. Nowadays, a lot of this data is generated on edge devices such as mobile phones, sensors, vehicles, and medical devices. The common strategy is to gather these samples at a computationally powerful server, which uses them to train its model [3]. Due to privacy and locality concerns, uploading of data sets, such as images and text messages, may be undesirable. Furthermore, the communication link between edge devices and the server can be heavily burdened by sharing of massive data sets.

These difficulties can be tackled by exploiting the increased computational power of mobile devices via mobile edge computing, in which training and inference is performed directly at network edges without having to share the raw data. In such systems, learning from distributed data and communicating between the edge server and devices are two critical and coupled aspects. This motivates the edge learning framework of federated learning (FL), which features distributed learning at edge devices with centralized aggregations, orchestrated by an edge server, and is the focus of growing research attention over the last few years [4, 5, 6]. The fact that the complete data set is not available to the server leads to several core challenges that are not encountered in conventional machine learning methods. In this paper we focus on two of the main challenges in FL: Noise induced by the shared channel due to the communication bottleneck, and statistical heterogeneity of usersâ€™ data.

The communication bottleneck in FL arises from the need for a large number of users to repeatedly and concurrently send their intermediate learned models (e.g., deep neural networks weights) to the server over shared and resource-limited wireless networks. A commonly adopted strategy to tackle this challenge is to model the wireless channel as a set of independent error-free bit-limited links between the users and the server, e.g., by using frequency division multiplexing (FDM), and then to apply methods of compressing the conveyed model parameters via quantization [7, 8, 9] or sparsification [10, 11]. This, however, results in each user being assigned a dedicated bandwidth which decreases with the number of participating users, increasing the energy consumption required to meet a desirable communication rate, and decreasing in the overall throughput and training speed. An alternative approach is to allow the users to simultaneously utilize the complete temporal and spectral resources of the uplink Multiple Access Channel (MAC) in a non-orthogonal manner, and in this way exploit the inherent aggregation carried out by the shared channel as a form of over-the-air (OTA) computation [12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18].

Recently, OTA has been studied in the FL context [19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27]. This approach allows each transmitter to utilize the complete available channel resources, e.g., bandwidth, regardless of the number of users. However, this results in channel noise directly affecting the model weights. This may degrade the accuracy of the trained model as SGD is known to be sensitive to noisy observations [28]. In [20], the authors considered scenario where the model updates are sparse with an identical sparsity pattern, which is not likely to hold when the data is heterogeneous. In [29, 30], the authors used a Bayesian aggregation procedure to handle the channel noise and fading. However, they considered distributed application of full gradient descent optimization over noisy channels with a single local step at each round, which is less efficient in terms of communication and computation resources as compared to FedAvg.

In our previous work, we proposed the COTAF algorithm [31] which facilitates high throughput FL over wireless channels, while preserving the convergence properties of the common FedAvg method for distributed learning, by introducing a time-varying precoding at the users. While COTAF has demonstrated some success in handling noise, in this work we take an additional step towards better noise reduction. By exploiting the prior distribution of local weights and the channel distribution, we address the noise challenge in OTA FL using a Bayesian approach, introducing the Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated-learning (BAAF) algorithm. Similarly to previous OTA FL methods, BAAF utilizes the fact that the model updates in FL are typically transmitted to be averaged, and uses OTA transmissions for increasing the throughput when operating over a shared channel. The transmission is then judiciously designed such that the received noisy signal at the server follows a Bayesian combining strategy. Specifically, we jointly exploit the distribution of the local models and the communication channels when aggregating the noisy local models received by the server, and estimate the noise-free sum of local models. Under the premise that the prior distributions of the local models are jointly Gaussian and the channel is Gaussian with block fading, this aggregation method is optimal in the sense of minimizing the mean-squared error (MSE) per communication round.

We analyze theoretically the convergence of models trained by BAAF, when the objective is a strongly convex and smooth function with bounded gradients, as commonly assumed for purposes of theoretical analysis in FL convergence studies [32, 33]. We rigorously show the effect of our MMSE estimation on the convergence of the algorithm compared to FedAvg that assumed noise-free and fading-free channels, and show superior theoretical performance over [31] in handling the noise under the same statistical model. Specifically, BAAF achieves the same convergence rate as FedAvg, with an additional noise term which depends on the MSE of our aggregation strategy and decays as 1/R1ğ‘…1/R, where Rğ‘…R is the number of communication rounds. We show explicitly that our error term convergences to zero with a higher rate compared to the corresponding term in [31]. We also analyze the performance of BAAF numerically, and demonstrate its improved performance over conventional OTA FL and over the COTAF algorithm.

Our second contribution is the extension of our results to FL with statistical heterogeneity among usersâ€™ data sets. Statistical heterogeneity implies that the data generating distributions vary among different sets of users [32]. This is often the case in FL, as the data available at each userâ€™s device is likely to be personalized. Statistical heterogeneity implies that when training several instances of a model on multiple edge devices, each instance may be biased. While FedAvg [4] is a very popular algorithm for FL, implementing it on heterogeneous data results in slow and unstable convergence due to the drift in the local updates. Several solutions have been suggested to address statistical heterogeneity, such as adding a regularizer to ensure users updates remain close [34], using a primal-dual optimization perspective [35], and more [36, 37, 38, 39, 40, 41, 42, 32, 43, 44, 45].

In this work we adopt the technique used in the SCAFFOLD algorithm [42], which uses control variates to reduce the user-drift and ensure that the user updates are aligned with each other. Specifically, SCAFFOLD estimates the update direction (i.e., gradient) for the server model (cğ‘c) and the update direction for each user cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} referred to as a control variant. The difference (câˆ’ciğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–c-c_{i}) is then an estimate of the user-drift which is used to correct the local update, as we elaborate on Section IV. This strategy successfully overcomes heterogeneity and converges in a significantly smaller number of communication rounds compared to FedAvg. However, SCAFFOLD is implemented in an ideal scenario assuming that the received local models at the server are error-free. Here, we implement the technique of control variates over noisy channels, and analyze the trade-off between the errors corresponding to heterogeneity and channel noise on the convergence rate. To handle statistical heterogeneity of users data, we extend BAAF and develop the COBAAF algorithm. First, we use control variates in the local updates of the users to address the drift induced by the statistical heterogeneity of the data. Then, similarly to BAAF, we use OTA transmission for both models and controls variates with an appropriate precoding, and implement minimum mean-square error (MMSE) estimation to mitigate the noise effect. Finally, the estimated global model and control vairates are distributed to the users for another round.

We analyze the convergence of models trained by COBAAF in heterogeneous and noisy environments to the minimal achievable loss function. We rigorously show the effect of our MMSE aggregation on the convergence of the algorithm compared to SCAFFOLD [42] that assumed noise-free and fading-free channels, and show superior performances over COTAF [31] in terms of coping with statistical heterogeneity. We further exploit an important trade-off between the channel error (determined by the MSE of the Bayesian estimation) and the heterogeneity error (determined by the gradient dissimilarity parameter). Finally, we analyze the performance of COBAAF numerically, and demonstrate its improved convergence compared to existing algorithms in simulation results.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows: Section II briefly reviews the FedAvg algorithm and some of its relevant extensions, and presents the system model of Bayesian OTA FL. Section III presents the BAAF algorithm along with its theoretical convergence analysis. In Section IV we present the extension to the heterogeneous setting and present the COBAAF algorithm along with its convergence analysis. Numerical results are described in Section V. Finally, Section VI provides concluding remarks. Detailed proofs of our main results are given in the appendix.

II System Model and Problem Formulation

In this section we detail the system model for which BAAF is derived. In Section IV we extend BAAF to cope with the heterogeneous nature of FL, and present the COBAAF algorithm.

II-B Federated Averaging

Federated Averaging (FedAvg) is a distributed learning algorithm aimed at recovering (4), without having the users share their local data. We first present the algorithm when executed over an error-free channel. The iterative algorithm carries out multiple training rounds, each consisting of the following three phases:

    where ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r)=âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r,Î¾i,kâˆ’1)subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘–ğ‘˜1{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r})=\nabla f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r},\xi_{i,k-1}) is an unbiased stochastic gradient of fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} at local step kğ‘˜k satisfying ğ”¼Î¾â€‹[ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½)]=âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğœ½)subscriptğ”¼ğœ‰delimited-[]subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–ğœ½âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğœ½\mathbb{E}_{\xi}[{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})]=\nabla f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}), and Î·ğœ‚\eta is the step size.

The uplink transmission in this algorithm is typically executed over an error-free channel with limited throughput, where channel noise and fading are assumed to be eliminated. In this paper, we consider transmissions in practical wireless networks, and we thus address the aggregated scheme in the present of channel noise and channel fading, as detailed in the sequel.

II-C Statistical and Communication Channel Model

As commonly assumed in OTA FL studies (see e.g., [31, 20, 26, 46]), the Nğ‘N users transmit their data to the server via a MAC, since the uplink communication is typically notably more constrained as compared to its downlink counterpart in terms of throughput. The downlink channel used for server transmissions is modeled as supporting reliable communications at arbitrary rates.

We next formulate the uplink channel model. Each user conveys its local model ğœ½irâ‰œğœ½i,Krâ‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r} to a channel input ğ’™irsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r} (which we define precisely in Section III-A). Wireless channels are inherently a shared and noisy media. We now present the statistical framework for our aggregation scheme. The motivation of our proposed algorithm is to find an optimal aggregation method of local weights from a Bayesian viewpoint. Characterizing the prior distribution of local weights is very challenging because it not only depends on the loss function but also on the underlying distribution of data samples. To overcome this difficulty, we model the distribution of the local weights as a Gaussian prior distribution with a proper moment matching technique. Specifically, we model the dğ‘‘d elements of ğœ½ir=[Î¸ir,1,â€¦â€‹Î¸ir,d]superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ1â€¦superscriptsubscriptğœƒğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘‘{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}=[\theta_{i}^{r,1},\ldots\theta_{i}^{r,d}] as i.i.d Gaussian random variables with common mean Î¼irsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\mu_{i}^{r} and variance (Ïƒir)2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ2(\sigma_{i}^{r})^{2}, which can be computed by performing offline simulations over a smaller data set, and therefore can be stored prior to the execution of the algorithm. The prior distribution can change over communication rounds according to the underlying distribution of data samples and the local loss function. We assume that ğœ½irsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} and ğœ½nrsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}^{r} are uncorrelated for iâ‰ nğ‘–ğ‘›i\neq n, as assumed in [29].

III The Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated-learning (BAAF) Algorithm

III-A Algorithm Design

We now present the proposed BAAF algorithm. First, we adapt the method proposed in [31], where each user first precodes its model update ğœ½irâˆ’ğœ½i,0rsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–0ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r} into the MAC channel input ğ’™irsuperscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r} via:

ğ’™ir=Î±râ€‹(ğœ½irâˆ’ğœ½i,0r),superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–0ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}=\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}), (8)

where Î±rsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ\sqrt{\alpha^{r}} is a precoding factor set to gradually amplify the model updates as rğ‘Ÿr progresses, while satisfying the power constraint (7). The precoder Î±rsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ\sqrt{\alpha^{r}} is given by

Î±râ‰œPmaxiâ¡ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğœ½irâˆ’ğœ½i,0râ€–2].â‰œsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–0ğ‘Ÿ2\alpha^{r}\triangleq\frac{P}{\max_{i}\mathbb{E}[||{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}||^{2}]}. (9)

The precoding parameter Î±rsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿ\sqrt{\alpha^{r}} depends on the distribution of the updated model, which depends on the distribution of the data. It can thus be computed by performing offline simulations with smaller data sets and distributing the numerically computed coefficients among the users, as we do in our numerical study in Section V. Alternatively, when the loss function has bounded gradients, this term can be replaced with a coefficient that is determined by the bound on the norm of the gradients (see [31]).

In each communication round, the server thus receives the noisy sum of local model updates:

(10)

Finally, the server aims to estimate the average ğœ½r=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğœ½irsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}. Eq.Â (14) is proved in Appendix B. We note that in order to evaluate the estimator in (14), the server requires to know Î¼irsuperscriptsubscriptğœ‡ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\mu_{i}^{r}, (Ïƒir)2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ2(\sigma_{i}^{r})^{2} and Ïƒw2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¤2\sigma_{w}^{2}. User iğ‘–i can send these parameters using a powerful channel code (e.g., polar codes) so that the server perfectly decodes them. When ğœ½irsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} and ğœ½nrsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘›ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{n}^{r} are correlated or when the elements of ğœ½irsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r} are not statistically identical, the estimation in (14) is suboptimal. Nevertheless, BAAF is still a promising algorithm due to its computational scalability in both the number of mobile devices and the model size at the cost of an MSE performance loss, and numerical experiments presented in Section V indicate that BAAF indeed mitigates effectively the channel noise.

After computing the estimated sum in (14), the server sends back ğœ½^MMSErsuperscriptsubscriptbold-^ğœ½MMSEğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}}_{\text{MMSE}}^{r} to the users, and the local model is updated by: ğœ½i,0r+1=ğœ½^MMSErsubscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘–0superscriptsubscriptbold-^ğœ½MMSEğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r+1}_{i,0}={\boldsymbol{\hat{\theta}}}_{\text{MMSE}}^{r}. ğœ½i,kr+1=ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r+1âˆ’Î·lâ€‹ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r+1),k=1,â€¦,K.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğœ‚ğ‘™subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘˜1â€¦ğ¾{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k}^{r+1}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r+1}-\eta_{l}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r+1}),k=1,\ldots,K. The pseudocode of BAAF is given in Algorithm 1.

III-B Theoretical Analysis

Our analysis is carried out under standard strong-convexity, smoothness, and bounded gradients assumptions used in SGD and FL studies (see e.g., [32, 33, 31, 20]):
AS1: Each function fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is Î²ğ›½\beta-smooth and Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex.

We next present the resulted MMSE estimation error.

Proposition 1

Theorem 1

Then, there exist weights {wr}subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘Ÿ\{w_{r}\} and local step sizes Î·lâ‰¤18â€‹Î²â€‹Kâ€‹(1+B2)subscriptğœ‚ğ‘™18ğ›½ğ¾1superscriptğµ2\eta_{l}\leq\frac{1}{8\beta K(1+B^{2})} such that the output (16) of the BAAF algorithm for any Râ‰¥8â€‹Î²â€‹(1+B2)Î¼ğ‘…8ğ›½1superscriptğµ2ğœ‡R\geq\frac{8\beta(1+B^{2})}{\mu} satisfies:

ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğœ½Â¯R)]âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğœ½âˆ—)ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹superscriptbold-Â¯ğœ½ğ‘…ğ¹superscriptğœ½\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F({\boldsymbol{\bar{\theta}}}^{R})]-F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})
â‰¤(3â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1+N)Î¼â€‹Râ€‹Kâ€‹N+3â€‹dâ€‹M2â€‹ÏƒÎ¸Î¼â€‹Râ€‹N2â€‹P)â‹…logâ¡(maxâ¡{Î¼2â€‹Râ€‹d0c1})absentâ‹…3superscriptğœ21ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘…ğ¾ğ‘3ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘€2subscriptğœğœƒğœ‡ğ‘…superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ƒsuperscriptğœ‡2ğ‘…subscriptğ‘‘0subscriptğ‘1\displaystyle\leq\left(\frac{3\sigma^{2}(1+N)}{\mu RKN}+\frac{3dM^{2}\sigma_{\theta}}{\mu RN^{2}P}\right)\cdot\log(\max\{\mu^{2}R\frac{d_{0}}{c_{1}}\})

The proof is given in Appendix C. Theorem 1 gives a clean expression of how the four termsâ€“ the initial distance due to the error in the initial estimate, the variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} due to the stochastic gradients, the error ÏƒÎ¸subscriptğœğœƒ\sigma_{\theta} due to the noisy channel and the gradient dissimilarity parameter G2superscriptğº2G^{2} â€“ characterize the error bound.

Comparing Theorem 1 to the corresponding convergence rate of FedAvg derived in [42, Theorem 1], which considered noise-free channels, we observe that BAAF achieves the same convergence rate, with an additional term which depends on the MSE induced by the channel noise. Larger MSEs make the convergence speed slower. By using the MMSE aggregation function that provides the minimum MSE, we can speed up the convergence rate. Additionally, by increasing Nğ‘N this distortion term diminishes. When the MSE equals to 00 (i.e., when ÏƒÎ¸=0subscriptğœğœƒ0\sigma_{\theta}=0), Theorem 1 coincides with [42, Theorem 1]. Additionally, comparing Theorem 1 to the corresponding result in [31], which does not apply MMSE estimation to the channel output, we observe that the error term that depends on the channel noise in BAAF, ÏƒÎ¸/Psubscriptğœğœƒğ‘ƒ\sigma_{\theta}/P, is smaller than the corresponding term Ïƒw2/Psuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¤2ğ‘ƒ\sigma_{w}^{2}/P obtained in [31], which improves the convergence result.

Finally, the gradient dissimilarity parameter G2superscriptğº2G^{2} term in Th.Â 1 determines the decrease in the convergence rate as a result of the user-drift, which is a result of the non i.i.d nature of the usersâ€™ data (i.e., the functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} are distinct). In more details, let ğœ½âˆ—superscriptğœ½{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*} be the global optimum of Fâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ¹ğœ½F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}), and ğœ½iâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{*} be the optimum of each userâ€™s loss function fiâ€‹(ğœ½)subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğœ½f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}). In the case of heterogeneous data, it is quite likely that each of these ğœ½iâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{*} is far away from the other, and from the global optimum ğœ½âˆ—superscriptğœ½{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}. The difference between 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğœ½iâˆ—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{*} (which is the server update) and the true optimum ğœ½âˆ—superscriptğœ½{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*} results in a user-drift. In the next section, we use the technique of control variates [42, 41] to mitigate this effect.

IV The Controlled Bayesian Air Aggregation Federated learning (COBBAF) Algorithm

We now extend the BAAF algorithm by implementing a variance reduction technique in the form of control variates in the local updates, thus reducing the negative effect of users-drift.

IV-A Federated Averaging with Control Variates

The local updates of FedAvg (as in BAAF) leads to a drift in the update of each user resulting in slow and unstable convergence. We thus develop COBAAF using the technique of control variates for the local updates. As proposed in [42, 41], along with the server model ğœ½ğœ½{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, in each round rğ‘Ÿr we maintain a state for each user (user control variate ğ’„irâ‰œğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½râˆ’1)â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1})) and for the server (server control variate ğ’„râ‰œ1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ’„irâ‰œsuperscriptğ’„ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r}\triangleq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}). We first present the algorithm when executed over an error-free channel. The iterative algorithm carries out multiple training rounds, each consisting of the following three phases:

  1. 1.

    In global round rğ‘Ÿr, starting from the shared model ğœ½i,0r=ğœ½râˆ’1subscriptsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿğ‘–0superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}_{i,0}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}, each user iğ‘–i trains its local model using its local data set and the control variates over Kğ¾K SGD local steps, namely,

    ğœ½i,kr=ğœ½i,kâˆ’1râˆ’Î·lâ€‹(ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r)âˆ’ğ’„irâˆ’1+ğ’„râˆ’1),superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğ’„ğ‘Ÿ1\begin{array}[]{c}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k}^{r}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}-\eta_{l}({\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r})-{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r-1}+{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r-1}),\end{array} (19)
  2. 2.

    Each user iğ‘–i then updates the control variate: ğ’„ir=ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½râˆ’1)superscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}={\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}).

  3. 3.

    Each user iğ‘–i conveys its trained local model ğœ½i,Krsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r} and the updated control variate ğ’„irsuperscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r} to the central server, which averages them into a global model via ğœ½r=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğœ½i,Krsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ¾ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,K}^{r}, and a global control variate ğ’„r=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Nğ’„irsuperscriptğ’„ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}, and sends the new model and control to the users for another round.

We next briefly explain the rationale behind the design of the algorithm. If communication is not a concern, then the ideal local update of user iğ‘–i at global round rğ‘Ÿr would be ğœ½i,kr=ğœ½i,kâˆ’1râˆ’1Nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Nğ’ˆjâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r)superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k}^{r}={\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{j}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}). Such an update essentially computes an unbiased gradient of Fâ€‹(ğœ½)ğ¹ğœ½F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}) and hence becomes equivalent to running FedAvg in the i.i.d. case (which is known to have strong performance). Unfortunately, such an update requires communicating with all users for every update step. Instead, the procedure above uses control variates such that ğ’„i=ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½râˆ’1)subscriptğ’„ğ‘–subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}={\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}) and ğ’„=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Nğ’„jğ’„1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğ’„ğ‘—{\boldsymbol{c}}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{j} for the whole round rğ‘Ÿr. Since the gradient of fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} is Lipschitz, it is expected that ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½râˆ’1)â‰ˆğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r)subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1})\approx{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}) as long as the local updates are not too large and ğœ½râˆ’1â‰ˆğœ½i,kâˆ’1rsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}\approx{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}. Then, the ideal update is estimated by: (ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r)âˆ’ğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½râˆ’1)+1Nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Nğ’ˆjâ€‹(ğœ½râˆ’1))â‰ˆ1Nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Nğ’ˆjâ€‹(ğœ½i,kâˆ’1r)subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ11ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ11ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğ’ˆğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘˜1ğ‘Ÿ({\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r})-{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1})+\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{j}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}))\approx\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}{\boldsymbol{g}}_{j}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,k-1}^{r}). Thus, the local updates do not drift and remain synchronized and converge under heterogeneous users.

We next address the aggregated scheme of COBAAF in the present of channel noise.

IV-B Communication and Statistical Model

In the iterative algorithm presented above the users are required to send additional information to the server, the controls ğ’„iâ‰œğ’ˆiâ€‹(ğœ½râˆ’1)â‰œsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–subscriptğ’ˆğ‘–superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}\triangleq{\boldsymbol{g}}_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}). IV-D Theoretical Analysis

We next establish a finite-sample bound on the error of the COBAAF algorithm, given by the expected loss in the objective value at global round Rğ‘…R with respect to Fâ€‹(ğœ½âˆ—)ğ¹superscriptğœ½F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}).

Theorem 2

Suppose that each of the functions fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} satisfies assumptions AS1,AS2. Then, there exist weights {wr}subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘Ÿ\{w_{r}\} and local step sizes Î·lâ‰¤18â€‹Î²â€‹Ksubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™18ğ›½ğ¾\eta_{l}\leq\frac{1}{8\beta K} such that the output (16) of the COBAAF algorithm for any Râ‰¥8â€‹Î²Î¼ğ‘…8ğ›½ğœ‡R\geq\frac{8\beta}{\mu} satisfies:

ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğœ½Â¯R)]âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğœ½âˆ—)ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹superscriptbold-Â¯ğœ½ğ‘…ğ¹superscriptğœ½\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[F({\boldsymbol{\bar{\theta}}}^{R})]-F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*})
â‰¤\displaystyle\leq (2â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹(1+N)Î¼â€‹Râ€‹Kâ€‹N+2â€‹dâ€‹M2â€‹ÏƒÎ¸Î¼â€‹Râ€‹Kâ€‹N2â€‹P+2â€‹dâ€‹M2â€‹Ïƒcâ€‹(1+Nâ€‹K)Î¼â€‹Râ€‹Kâ€‹N2â€‹P)2superscriptğœ21ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘…ğ¾ğ‘2ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘€2subscriptğœğœƒğœ‡ğ‘…ğ¾superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ƒ2ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘€2subscriptğœğ‘1ğ‘ğ¾ğœ‡ğ‘…ğ¾superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ƒ\displaystyle\left(\frac{2\sigma^{2}(1+N)}{\mu RKN}+\frac{2dM^{2}\sigma_{\theta}}{\mu RKN^{2}P}+\frac{2dM^{2}\sigma_{c}(1+NK)}{\mu RKN^{2}P}\right)

where Ïƒcr=maxrâˆˆ[R],mâˆˆ[d]â¡Ïƒcrsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘Ÿsubscriptformulae-sequenceğ‘Ÿdelimited-[]ğ‘…ğ‘šdelimited-[]ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘Ÿ\sigma_{c}^{r}=\max_{r\in[R],m\in[d]}\sigma_{c}^{r}, Ïƒcrâ‰œÏƒw21+Ïƒw2Î²râ€‹âˆ‘i=1N(vir)2â‰œsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¤21superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘¤2superscriptğ›½ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ2\sigma_{c}^{r}\triangleq\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{1+\frac{\sigma_{w}^{2}}{\beta^{r}\sum_{i=1}^{N}(v_{i}^{r})^{2}}}, c3=Ïƒ2â€‹(1+N)Kâ€‹N+dâ€‹M2â€‹ÏƒÎ¸Kâ€‹N2â€‹P+dâ€‹M2â€‹Ïƒcâ€‹(1+Nâ€‹K)Kâ€‹N2â€‹Psubscriptğ‘3superscriptğœ21ğ‘ğ¾ğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘€2subscriptğœğœƒğ¾superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ƒğ‘‘superscriptğ‘€2subscriptğœğ‘1ğ‘ğ¾ğ¾superscriptğ‘2ğ‘ƒc_{3}=\frac{\sigma^{2}(1+N)}{KN}+\frac{dM^{2}\sigma_{\theta}}{KN^{2}P}+\frac{dM^{2}\sigma_{c}(1+NK)}{KN^{2}P}.

The proof is given in Appendix D.

Similarly to Theorem 1, Theorem 2 gives a clean expression of how the four termsâ€“ the initial distance due to the error in the initial estimate, the variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} due to the stochastic gradients, and the errors ÏƒÎ¸subscriptğœğœƒ\sigma_{\theta}, Ïƒcsubscriptğœğ‘\sigma_{c} due to the noisy channel â€“ characterize the error bound. Comparing Theorem 2 to the corresponding result in [42], which considered noise-free channels, we observe that COBAAF achieves the same convergence rate, with an additional terms which depend on the MSE induced by the channel noise and fading. Larger MSEs make the convergence speed slower. By using the MMSE aggregation function that provides the minimum MSE, we can speed up the convergence rate. Additionally, by increasing Nğ‘N this distortion term diminishes. When the MSE equals 00, Theorem 2 coincides with [42, Theorem 3]. Additionally, comparing Theorem 2 to the corresponding result in Theorem 1 and in [31], which considered the same setup but without addressing the statistical heterogeneity, we observe that Theorem 1 and Theorem 111 in [31] have an additional component which depends on G2superscriptğº2G^{2} and Î“â‰œFâˆ—âˆ’1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1Nfnâˆ—â‰œÎ“superscriptğ¹1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘›\Gamma\triangleq F^{*}-\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}f_{n}^{*}, respectively, that encapsulates the degree of heterogeneity. The use of control variates in COBAAF mitigates the negative effect of this term on the convergence.

Theorem 2 implies an important trade-off between communication and heterogeneity: To reduce heterogeneity, the users are required to send the additional parameters ğ’„isubscriptğ’„ğ‘–{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}, which results in the error term Ïƒcsubscriptğœğ‘\sigma_{c}. However, the use of the control variates mitigates the negative effect of the dissimilarity term G2superscriptğº2G^{2} on the convergence. Finally, note that due to the OTA transmission of the COBAAF algorithm, the bandwidth requirement is independent of the number of users Nğ‘N, allowing the simultaneous participation of a large number of users without limiting the throughput of each user. Practically, this transmission scheme requires coherent transmissions between users [5].

IV-E Extension to Fading Channels

In the previous subsections we focused on FL over noisy MACs, where h~ir=1superscriptsubscript~â„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ1\tilde{h}_{i}^{r}=1 for all r,iğ‘Ÿğ‘–r,i. Here, we extend COBAAF to handle transmissions over fading MAC with general fading values, while preserving its proven convergence (the extension of BAAF to fading MACs can be done similarly). In fading MACs, the signal transmitted by each user undergoes a fading coefficient denoted by hirâ€‹ejâ€‹Ï•irsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿh_{i}^{r}e^{j\phi_{i}^{r}} as defined in (6) for the local model updates, and Ïirâ€‹ejâ€‹Ï†irsuperscriptsubscriptğœŒğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‘ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\rho_{i}^{r}e^{j\varphi_{i}^{r}} for the control variates. In the extension here, we assume that the participating entities have channel state information (CSI), i.e., knowledge of the fading coefficients, as commonly assumed in wireless communications and particularly OTA FL (see e.g., [48, 49, 31] and subsequent studies). Such knowledge can be obtained by letting the users sense their channels, estimating the channel from pilot signals, or having the access point/server periodically estimate these coefficients and convey them to the users.

Following the scheme proposed in [31], each user utilizes its CSI to cancel the fading effect by amplifying the signal by its inverse channel coefficient. However, weak channels might cause an arbitrarily high amplification, possibly violating the transmission power constraint (7). Therefore, thresholds hmin,Ïminsubscriptâ„subscriptğœŒh_{\min},\rho_{\min} are set, and users observing fading coefficients of a lesser magnitude than hminsubscriptâ„h_{\min} (for the model updates) or ÏminsubscriptğœŒ\rho_{\min} (for the control variates) do not transmit in that communication round. As channels typically attenuate their signals, it holds that hmin<1,Ïmin<1formulae-sequencesubscriptâ„1subscriptğœŒ1h_{\min}<1,\rho_{\min}<1. Under this extension of COBAAF, (8) becomes

ğ’™ir={Î±râ€‹hminhirâ€‹eâˆ’jâ€‹Ï•irâ€‹(ğœ½irâˆ’ğœ½i,0r),ifâ€‹hir>hmin,0,ifâ€‹hirâ‰¤hmin.superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿcasessuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„superscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–0ğ‘Ÿifsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„0ifsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}\!=\!\begin{cases}\frac{\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}h_{\min}}{h_{i}^{r}}e^{-j\phi_{i}^{r}}({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}),&\text{if}\;h_{i}^{r}>h_{\min},\\ 0,&\text{if}\;h_{i}^{r}\leq h_{\min}.\end{cases} (29)

Note that the energy constraint (7) is preserved. The control variates cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} are transmitted in a similar way.

To formulate the server aggregation, we let ğ’®râŠ‚ğ’©superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿğ’©\mathcal{S}^{r}\subset\mathcal{N} be the set of user indices whose corresponding channel at round rğ‘Ÿr satisfies hir>hminsuperscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„h_{i}^{r}>h_{\min}, Ïir>ÏminsuperscriptsubscriptğœŒğ‘–ğ‘ŸsubscriptğœŒ\rho_{i}^{r}>\rho_{\min}. As the server has CSI, it knows ğ’®rsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}^{r}, and can thus recover the aggregated model ğœ½rsuperscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r} and control ğ’„rsuperscriptğ’„ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r} in a similar manner as in (22), via

ğœ½~r=ğ’š~r|ğ’®r|â€‹Î±râ€‹hmin+ğœ½râˆ’1ğ’„~r=ğ’›~r|ğ’®r|â€‹Î²râ€‹Ïmin,formulae-sequencesuperscript~ğœ½ğ‘Ÿsuperscript~ğ’šğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„superscriptğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1superscript~ğ’„ğ‘Ÿsuperscript~ğ’›ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘ŸsubscriptğœŒ\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}=\frac{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{y}}}^{r}}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\sqrt{\alpha^{r}}h_{\min}}+{\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{r-1}\;\quad\quad\tilde{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r}=\frac{\tilde{{\boldsymbol{z}}}^{r}}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\sqrt{\beta^{r}}\rho_{\min}}, (30)

which can be equivalently written as:

ğœ½~r=1|ğ’®r|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®rğœ½ir+N|ğ’®r|â€‹hminâ€‹ğ’˜r,superscript~ğœ½ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„superscriptğ’˜ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}+\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|h_{\min}}{\boldsymbol{w}}^{r},
ğ’„~r=1|ğ’®r|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®rğ’„ir+N|ğ’®r|â€‹Ïminâ€‹ğ’r.superscript~ğ’„ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘superscriptğ’®ğ‘ŸsubscriptğœŒsuperscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle\tilde{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum\limits_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}+\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\rho_{\min}}{\boldsymbol{n}}^{r}. (31)

As in Section IV-C, given ğœ½~r,ğ’„~rsuperscript~ğœ½ğ‘Ÿsuperscript~ğ’„ğ‘Ÿ\tilde{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r},\tilde{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r}, the server estimates the partial sums 1|ğ’®r|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®rğœ½ir1superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}, 1|ğ’®r|â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®rğ’„ir1superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}, using the MMSE estimator, and sends the estimators ğœ½^r,ğ’„^rsuperscript^ğœ½ğ‘Ÿsuperscript^ğ’„ğ‘Ÿ\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r},\hat{{\boldsymbol{c}}}^{r} to the users for the next round.

Comparing (IV-E) to the corresponding equivalent formulation in (23), we note that the proposed extension of COBAAF results in two main differences from the fading-free scenario: First, the presence of fading is translated into an increase in the noise power, encapsulated in the constants N|ğ’®r|â€‹hmin>1ğ‘superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsubscriptâ„1\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|h_{\min}}>1, N|ğ’®r|â€‹Ïmin>1ğ‘superscriptğ’®ğ‘ŸsubscriptğœŒ1\frac{N}{|\mathcal{S}^{r}|\rho_{\min}}>1. Second, fewer models are aggregated in each round as ğ’®râ‰¤Nsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿğ‘\mathcal{S}^{r}\leq N. The set of participating users ğ’®rsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}^{r} depends on the distribution of the fading coefficients. Thus, in order to analytically characterize how the convergence is affected by fading compared to the scenario analyzed in Subsection IV-D, we introduce the following assumption:
AS4: At each communication round, the participating users set ğ’®rsuperscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{S}^{r} contains Sâ‰¤Nğ‘†ğ‘S\leq N users and is uniformly distributed over all the subsets of ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} of cardinality Sğ‘†S. Note that Assumption AS4 can be imposed by a simple distributed mechanism using an opportunistic carrier sensing as described in [31].

We point out that the partial aggregation scheme induces some â€™lagâ€™ in our updates of the control variates ğ’„isubscriptğ’„ğ‘–{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i} since only a small subset of them are updated at each round. That is, the global control ğ’„r=1Sâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’®rğ’„irsuperscriptğ’„ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘†subscriptğ‘–superscriptğ’®ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{c}}^{r}=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}^{r}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r} also drifts from the â€desiredâ€ average âˆ‘iâˆˆğ’©ğ’„irsubscriptğ‘–ğ’©superscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿ\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}{\boldsymbol{c}}_{i}^{r}. We address this point in the proof of Theorem 3.

Next, we characterize the convergence of the instantaneous global model, as stated in the following theorem:

Comparing Theorem 3 to the corresponding convergence bound with fading-free channels in Theorem 3 reveals that the extension of COBAAF allows the trained model to maintain its asymptotic convergence rate of Oâ€‹(1R)ğ‘‚1ğ‘…O(\frac{1}{R}) in the presence of fading channel conditions as well. However, the aforementioned differences in the equivalent global model due to fading are translated here into additive terms increasing the bound on the distance between the expected instantaneous objective ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğœ½Â¯R)]ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹superscriptbold-Â¯ğœ½ğ‘…\mathbb{E}[F({\boldsymbol{\bar{\theta}}}^{R})] and its desired optimal value. Moreover, due to the partial participation of users in the global rounds, we also need to keep track how far our control variate is from its value at the optimum as discussed above. This is encapsulated in the term D~2superscript~ğ·2\tilde{D}^{2}, which is different (and larger) than the corresponding D2superscriptğ·2D^{2} term in (2). V Numerical Analysis

We now provide simulation results to demonstrate the efficiency of BAAF and COBAAF, in both regression and classification tasks. We evaluate BAAF and COBAAF on real data sets. In order to better characterize statistical heterogeneity and study its effect on convergence, we also evaluate them on a set of synthetic data, which allows for more precise manipulation of statistical heterogeneity.

V-A Linear Regression on Synthetic Data

We consider a linear regression model with a convex local loss function, i.e., fiâ€‹(ğœ½)=â€–ğ‘¨iTâ€‹ğœ½âˆ’ğ‘©iâ€–22subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğœ½superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ‘‡ğœ½subscriptğ‘©ğ‘–22f_{i}({\boldsymbol{\theta}})=||{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i}^{T}{\boldsymbol{\theta}}-{\boldsymbol{B}}_{i}||_{2}^{2}, where ğ‘¨isubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i} is the training input and ğ‘©isubscriptğ‘©ğ‘–{\boldsymbol{B}}_{i} is the corresponding level, with [Di,d]=[100,10]subscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘‘10010[D_{i},d]=[100,10]. In Fig.Â 1, we present the performance evaluation when the number of users is N=20ğ‘20N=20, the number of local steps is K=10ğ¾10K=10 and the local step size is 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2}. To embrace the data heterogeneity, for each user iğ‘–i we model ğ‘¨iâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(ai,ğ‘°),aiâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(1,Î±),ğœ½iâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(bi,I),biâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(âˆ’4,Î²)formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ‘¨ğ‘–ğ’©subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ‘°formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ’©1ğ›¼formulae-sequencesimilar-tosubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ’©subscriptğ‘ğ‘–Isimilar-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğ’©4ğ›½{\boldsymbol{A}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(a_{i},{\boldsymbol{I}}),a_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(1,\alpha),{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(b_{i},\emph{I}),b_{i}\sim\mathcal{N}(-4,\beta), where I is the identity matrix. Therefore, Î±ğ›¼\alpha controls how much the local data at each user differs from that of other users, and Î²ğ›½\beta controls how much local models differ from each other. We simulate MACs with signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs) of 10dB and without fading. The precoding coefficients Î±r,Î²rsuperscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ›½ğ‘Ÿ\alpha^{r},\beta^{r} are computed via (9),(20), respectively, using numerical averaging, i.e., we carried out offline simulations of local SGD without noise and with 20%percent2020\% of the data samples, and computed the averaged norm of the resulting model updates. We numerically evaluate the gap from the achieved expected objective and the loss-minimizing one, i.e., ğ”¼â€‹[Fâ€‹(ğœ½^r)]âˆ’Fâ€‹(ğœ½âˆ—)ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ¹superscript^ğœ½ğ‘Ÿğ¹superscriptğœ½\mathbb{E}[F(\hat{{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}^{r})]-F({\boldsymbol{\theta}}^{*}). Using this performance measure, we compare BAAF and COBAAF to the following FL methods: (i) Non-precoded OTA FL (denoted in Fig.Â 1 as â€Noisy FedAvgâ€), where every user transmits its model updates over the MAC without time varying precoding (9) and with a constant amplification as in [31], i.e., ğ’™ir=Pâ€‹(ğœ½irâˆ’ğœ½i,0r)superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœ½ğ‘–0ğ‘Ÿ{\boldsymbol{x}}_{i}^{r}=P({\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i}^{r}-{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{i,0}^{r}); (ii) COTAF [31], in which a time varying precoding is implemented similarly as in (9), but without the use of control variates and without Bayesian aggregation at the server side; and (iii) SCAFFOLD [42] carried out over ideal orthogonal noiseless channels. The stochastic expectation is evaluated by averaging over 100100100 Monte Carlo trials, where in each trial the initial ğœ½0subscriptğœ½0{\boldsymbol{\theta}}_{0} is randomized from zero-mean Gaussian distribution with covariance ğ‘°dsubscriptğ‘°ğ‘‘{\boldsymbol{I}}_{d}.

It can be seen in Fig.Â 1 that BAAF (purple curve) outperforms both FedAvg carried over noisy channels (blue curve), and COTAF (red curve), indicating the gain that we achieve by using the proposed precoding scheme and Bayesian aggregation method at the server side. Note that COTAF uses precoding but does not implement Bayesian aggregation, thus the gap between BAAF and COTAF indicates the performance gain as a result of the Bayesian aggregation scheme. We also observe that COBAAF outperforms BAAF and COTAF. This implies that COBAAF indeed reduces the variance induced by heterogeneity using the control variates compared to BAAF and COTAF that do not use this technique. Note that BAAF uses precoding and implements Bayesian aggregation but does not use control variates in the local updates, thus the gap between COBAAF and BAAF indicates the performance gain as a result of the control variates. Finally, we also observe that COBAAF (green curve) achieves performances within a minor gap from that of SCAFFOLD [42] carried out over ideal orthogonal noiseless channels (pink curve). That indicates that COBAAF is able to mitigate the noise effect. It is emphasized that when using orthogonal transmissions, as implicitly assumed when using the conventional SCAFFOLD scheme, increasing the number of users implies that the channel resources must be shared among a larger number of users, hence the throughput of each user decreases. However, in OTA FL the throughput is independent of the number of users. The results presented in Fig.Â 1 demonstrate the benefits of COBAAF, as an OTA FL scheme which accounts for both the convergence properties of FL algorithms as well as the unique characteristics of wireless communication channels.

Next, we repeat the simulation study of Fig.Â 1 while increasing the number of users to be N=200ğ‘200N=200 in Fig.Â 2. The results demonstrate the dependence of COBAAF on the number of users Nğ‘N. Since the MSE resulting from the Bayesian aggregation decreases when Nğ‘N increases, increasing the number of users Nğ‘N improves the performance of COBAAF. In particular, COBAAF almost reaches the performance of noise-free SCAFFOLD.

Finally, we repeat the simulation study of Fig.Â 1 while increasing the number of local steps to be K=20ğ¾20K=20 in Fig.Â 3 Comparing Fig.Â 3 to Fig.Â 1 reveals that increasing the SGD steps Kğ¾K can improve the performance of COBAAF as the channel noise is induced less frequently. We also observe that the gap between COBAAF to COTAF increases compared to Fig.Â 1, since performing more local steps in heterogeneous systems increases the users drift in the COTAF algorithm. The control variates c,ciğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–c,c_{i} in COBAAF allows to utilize the local steps to improve the performance.

V-B Classification on MNIST Data set

Next, we consider an image classification problem, based on the MNIST data set [51], which contains train and test images from ten different digits. Our real data set experiments run logistic regression (convex) model as in [42]. We study two ways of partitioning the MNIST data over users: balanced partitioning, where the data is shuffled, and then partitioned into 10 users each receiving 600 examples, and imbalanced partitioning, where approximately 20%percent2020\% of the training data of each user is associated with a single label, which differs among the different users. Consequently, each user holds more images from a unique class, resulting in heterogeneity between the users. The model accuracy versus the transmission round achieved for the considered FL schemes is depicted in Figs.Â 4 and 5 for the homogeneous case and the heterogeneous case, respectively. We evaluate the performances when the number of local steps is K=5ğ¾5K=5, the number of users is N=10ğ‘10N=10, the SNR is 101010dB without fading, and the learning rate is 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2}.

Observing Fig.Â 4, we note that in the homogeneous setting, BAAF (green curve) outperforms both FedAvg over noisy channels (red curve), and COTAF (cyan curve), indicating the gain that we achieve also in this classification task by using the proposed precoding scheme and Bayesian aggregation method at the server side. The gap between BAAF and COTAF indicates the performance gain as a result of the Bayesian aggregation scheme. Finally, we also observe that BAAF achieves performances within a minor gap from that of FedAvg (purple curve) carried over ideal orthogonal noiseless channels (which has great performances in the homogeneous case).

Finally, in Fig.Â 5 we compared the performances of the algorithms in the MNIST classification task in the heterogeneous setting over noisy channels. We observe that the proposed CoBAAF algorithm outperforms COTAF, with a larger gap than in the homogeneous case. This is due to the ability of CoBAAF to handle heterogeneous data sets. By employing precoding and Bayesian aggregation, COBBAF is able to almost achieve the performance of SCAFFOLD over a noiseless channel.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we developed two OTA FL algorithms for combating noise and heterogeneity. Our proposed BAAF algorithm is based on a rigorous Bayesian approach for signal aggregation to mitigate the noise and fading effects induced by the channel. To handle heterogeneity, we developed COBAAF, which extends BAAF and uses a control variates technique. We rigorously prove that the BAAF and COBAAF converge to the loss minimizing model with the same asymptotic convergence rate of FedAvg [4] and SCAFFOLD [42] (respectively) without communication constraints. The strong performances of COBAAF are achieved by combining the transmission and Bayesian aggregation scheme, with proper updates at the user side. Numerical results demonstrate strong performance of the method.

Combining Eq.Â (D)-(47) we obtain a recursive equation for the COBAAF progress in one round:

+Î·~2â€‹[Ïƒ2Kâ€‹Nâ€‹(1+2â€‹N)+dâ€‹ÏƒcrN2â€‹Kâ€‹Î²râ€‹(12+K)]+dN2â€‹Î±râ€‹ÏƒÎ¸r.superscript~ğœ‚2delimited-[]superscriptğœ2ğ¾ğ‘12ğ‘ğ‘‘superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘2ğ¾superscriptğ›½ğ‘Ÿ12ğ¾ğ‘‘superscriptğ‘2superscriptğ›¼ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğœğœƒğ‘Ÿ\displaystyle+\tilde{\eta}^{2}\left[\frac{\sigma^{2}}{KN}(1+2N)+\frac{d\sigma_{c}^{r}}{N^{2}K\beta^{r}}(\frac{1}{2}+K)\right]+\frac{d}{N^{2}\alpha^{r}}\sigma_{\theta}^{r}.
